Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: AVATOL - Next Generation Phenomics for the Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
Darwin's theory of evolution explained that millions of species are related, and dealt biologists and paleontologists the enormous challenge of discovering the branching pattern of the Tree of Life. Work on this great challenge is producing a map of species-relatedness through Earth history, and answering questions such as "what is the closest relative of a species?" and "what species make important products?" To do this scientists draw on all heritable features, including genotypes (e.g., DNA) and phenotypes (e.g., anatomy). Studying phenotypes, however, has remained complicated and slow, because it has not been revolutionized by computer science and engineering innovations.

A team of biologists, computer scientists, and paleontologists will extend and adapt methods from computer vision, machine learning, crowd-sourcing and natural language processing to enable rapid and automated study of phenotypes for the Tree of Life on a vast scale. The three-year goal is to release large phenomic datasets built using new methods, and to provide the public and scientific community with tools for future work. Planned is the training of teachers and students (kindergarten - postdoctoral levels) and the engagement of "citizen scien-tists." Enormous phenomic datasets, many with images, will fill an important public interest in biodiversity and the fossil record.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In studying the evolution of phenotypic traits, one of the key rate-limiting steps is the acquisition of the phenotypic data  - which often requires significant tedious manual labor, usually from a scientific specialist.  The PI was part of a large collaborative team that developed a number of software tools aimed to significantly accelerate the acquisition of phenotypic data from images or text sources.  Her role in the project, as a microbial bioinformaticist, was to assist in the team’s development of two software products: MicroPIE (Microbial Phenomics Information Extractor) and MicrO (an ontology of prokaryotic traits and phenotypes).

MicroPIE (https://github.com/biosemantics/micropie2) is a java-based software tool for the rapid acquisition of prokaryotic phenotypic trait data from published text (taxonomic descriptions) and to output that data in the form of a raw matrix.  The raw matrix can then be converted into a scored matrix (e.g., a nexus file) using another tool: MatrixConverter (https://github.com/gburleigh/MatrixConverter).  MicroPIE works by first categorizing sentences in a taxonomic description using a supervised text classification algorithm.  For example, the sentence “DNA G+C content is 33.1-34.4% mol %.” is categorized as belonging to Category 1 (G+C content).  MicroPIE then uses a sub-algorithm to cluster key verb phrases for text extraction.  It also uses a set of regular expression, pattern match modules, and extensive Term Lists to facilitate text extraction.  Term Lists, derived from a corpus of >1000 taxonomic descriptions from the Archaea, Bacteroidetes, Cyanobacteria, and Mollicutes, contain character states and synonyms found in the corpus of taxonomic descriptions (e.g. terms for Cell Shape include: coccoid, coccoidal, coccus, coccobacillus, bacillus, rod).

Testing of MicroPIE performance shows that it massively accelerates our ability to acquire phenotypic trait data from the published taxonomic literature.  In an informal evaluation, MicroPIE took 47 minutes and 45 seconds to process the 111 descriptions and output a raw character matrix, running on a standard PC laptop.  In contrast, the same matrix took over 180 person-hours to manually construct from scratch.

Currently, MicroPIE reliably extracts information for some sentence categories (e.g., mol% G+C, cell length and width, cell relationships, Gram stain, pigments, motility, salt and pH ranges, antibiotic sensitivity, and colony shape, margin, and texture).  Overall, the recall and precision of extraction is >0.80 for more than 50% of the characters and >0.5 for most of the rest of the characters.  Additional algorithm development will be required in order to improve the extraction performance for other characters (cell shape, external cell features, colony color, host relationships, temperature range, aerophilicity, vitamins and co-factors, metabolic substrates, physiological tests, and fermentation substrates and products). 

MicrO is an ontology (a formal, hierarchical, logical network) of microbiological terms, including prokaryotic qualities and processes, material entities (such as cell components), chemical entities (such as microbiological culture media and medium ingredients), and assays.  Version 1.3 is available at https://github.com/carrineblank/MicrO.  The ontology was built to support the development of MicroPIE (in the future it will replace the Term Lists).  MicrO is rich in logical axioms and synonyms gathered from the taxonomic literature, captures the evolutionary diversity of phenotypes and metabolic processes across the tree of life, captures the diversity of synonyms and information contained in the taxonomic literature, and relates microbiological entities and processes to terms in other ontologies, such as the Gene Ontology (GO), the Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and the Chemical Entities of Biological Interest (ChEBI).  

MicrO was constructed using OWL Protégé, and follows OBO Foundry principles.  It imports terms from over 19 other ontologies and contains >22,000 logical axioms connecting entities and processes across multiple ontologies to increase higher-order knowledge of traits).  We designed MicrO such that it can support the ongoing and future development of algorithms that can leverage the controlled vocabulary and logical inference power provided by the ontology.  By connecting microbial classes with large numbers of chemical entities, material entities, biological processes, molecular functions, and qualities using a dense array of logical axioms, MicrO can be a powerful knowledgebase for the development of new bioinformatics tools.  For example, MicrO could support development of new tools that aim to identify novel connections between microbial phenotypes and genotypes (i.e., inferring the novel gene functionality in microbial genomes).  

Broader Impacts: this highly collaborative team published research products in multiple peer-reviewed journal articles (4 by the PI), multiple conference presentations (8 by the PI), software products (2 by the PI), published electronic data packages (5 by the PI), demonstrated tool functionality in teacher-training workshops, and involved many post-docs, graduate students, and undergraduate students (3 in the PI’s lab).
